awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Development of a digital therapeutic device for high tone pelvic floor disorders
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the potential development of a connected wireless device and app to guide users through pelvic floor physical therapy at home. In the United States today, over 33 million women suffer from high-tone pelvic floor dysfunction (HTPFD), a neuromuscular disorder of the pelvic floor characterized by non-relaxing pelvic floor muscles, resulting in voiding and defecatory symptoms, sexual dysfunction, and pelvic pain. Due to limited awareness of the condition and the need for a detailed myofascial pelvic exam for diagnosis, patients are often underdiagnosed and undertreated. Of women with HTPFD, only 5 million (less than 15%) complete first-line pelvic floor physical therapy treatment. Potential barriers to PFPT are well established and include the high cost/copay of treatment, time away from work, and distances traveled to a certified pelvic health physical therapist. The commercial application of the device is in addressing the unmet market need for a potentially effective, guided, self-treatment performed at home that may reduce the number of therapy sessions necessary for women to treat symptoms and improve self-treatment compliance. 

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a connected, wireless pelvic floor wand for the treatment of high-tone pelvic floor dysfunction (HTPFD).  The proposed technology could be an interactive pelvic wand designed to sense its position intra-vaginally and communicate with a smartphone application in real-time.  This project pursues a potentially disruptive solution to the current deficit in physical therapy telehealth. It could broaden the opportunity for HTPFD patients to initiate treatment in collaboration with physical therapy or alone. Proprietary spatial calibration technology will be designed to help potentially guide patients through targeted pelvic floor muscles and coaching sessions and real-time feedback will optimize pelvic floor muscle release. Using the proposed technology, patients may be able to track, review and share their progress over time.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.inst_name: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

por.por_cntn:
Erin Carey, PI, has completed the customer discovery project for I-Corps: "Development of a digital therapeutic device for high tone pelvic floor disorders". During the funding period 06/15/2022 to 05/31/2023 she attended two conferences to interview key stakeholders and clinical experts in the field of pelvic medicine. The first conference attended was the combined American Urogynecologic Society (AUGS) and International Urogynecological Association (IUGA) Scientific Meeting June 14-18, 2022 in Austin, Texas.  These societies are considered the premier non-profit organizations representing professionals who treat female pelvic floor dysfunction. This conference was attended with Jenn Harrington, co-inventor of the pelvic floor device and entrepreneurial lead on the project.  By attending this conference, her team was able to finalize our interview guide, perform initial interviews on-site and make invaluable contacts to schedule additional interviews during the NSF session.

During the NSF I-Corp program, Dr. Carey and the I-Corps team completed 103 interviews with 44 patients, 24 PTs, 22 other healthcare providers (i.e. gynecologists) as well as 13 possible industry partners. Her research led to the conclusion that self-directed manual therapy has therapeutic value, but there are three primary barriers to patients' home use of mechanical wands for this purpose: (1) fear of hurting themselves, (2) not knowing where to position the wand and how much force to use; and (3) general lack of confidence in the process and pelvic anatomy. This information supported the SmartWand in explicitly addressing all three barriers, as well as opening the door to more effective collaboration between physical therapists and their patients in the treatment of high tone pelvic floor dysfunction. These data were a direct result of end user and provider interviews.

During her funding period, Dr. Carey also traveled to the 49th Annual Scientific Meeting Society of Gynecologic Surgeons (SGS) March 19-22, 2023 in Tucson, Arizona. Here she followed up with a cohort of initial interviewees as well as new contacts, updating the team on the project status and included follow up interviews specific to the implementation of the Phase 1 project as well as Phase II planning and support.

With pertinent data directly obtained from the NSF grant, Dr. Carey and team submitted a Phase 1 SBIR September 5, 2022, 'A device to treat high tone pelvic floor dysfunction in women.'  A notice of award was received Monday May 29, 2023, from the Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute Of Child Health & Human Development of the National Institutes of Health, Award Number R43HD112277. In Phase I, they will develop a commercial, interactive, wireless device and app for women with high tone pelvic floor dysfunction. In Phase 2, the team will update the wand and app designs under design controls that comply with FDA requirements and manufacture enough devices for use in a clinical study to evaluate the clinical efficacy of the SmartWand.

 


Last Modified: 06/01/2023
Modified by: Erin T Carey
